The Mona Offshore Wind Farm Order 2025
summary: A new law allows the building, operation, and upkeep of a large offshore wind farm roughly 28 kilometers out in the Irish Sea from North Wales, aiming to boost renewable energy production and reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The project could support jobs during construction and long-term clean energy jobs, while aiding the UK’s climate goals. To make this work, the company behind it—Mona Offshore Wind Limited—has the power to acquire necessary land and override existing land rights, ensuring pathways for infrastructure like undersea cables and grid connections. Details about the project’s plans, funding guarantees, and legal documents are publicly available at the company’s Sunbury-on-Thames office for anyone to review. While this might stir debate among local communities or landowners, the wind farm could help stabilize energy prices and lower carbon emissions, marking a step toward greener power and potentially influencing future offshore projects.

title: The Solihull (Electoral Changes) Order 2025
summary: This law redraws Solihull’s council election map, creating 17 new wards by 2026 to update local representation without altering the town’s overall borders. The 2026 election will be a one-time “whole council” vote—where all seats are contested at once—before shifting back to staggered thirds the next year. Parish elections will follow the updated ward boundaries starting 2027. Residents might notice different voting districts and sharper political contrasts during the 2026 campaign, but the government says businesses, services, and daily life shouldn’t see major impacts. Full ward boundary details are publicly accessible online or in London.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (St Erme, Cornwall) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The Aviation Safety (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update UK aviation safety standards to simplify pilot licensing and flight operations. Key changes include: the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) can no longer issue new Light Aircraft Pilot Licences for aeroplanes, but gliding clubs can now offer training and assessments for sailplane pilots without seeking separate CAA approval, streamlining access to recreational flying. For cost-shared flights (where pilots split expenses with passengers), clearer guidelines define “direct costs” and regulate how such flights are advertised, aiming to prevent unlicensed commercial operations. Balloon pilot licenses are adjusted to balance safety with flexibility, allowing owners of older licenses to convert them into updated ratings while removing outdated medical certification requirements. The rules also cut red tape for training organizations, shifting safety-check responsibilities to instructors and examiners. Although few major economic or environmental impacts are expected, recreational pilots and gliding clubs may see reduced bureaucracy, while hobbyists sharing flight costs could benefit from clearer rules on legality.

title: The Football (Offences) (Designation of Football Matches) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This law updates the official list of football matches where disruptive behavior is banned, changing the names of certain competitions to match how they’re known today. The 1991 Football (Offences) Act makes it illegal to act disorderly—like sparking fights or throwing objects—at designated matches, and the current update ensures enforcement applies to the National League, Women’s Super League, Women’s Super League 2, and Cymru Premier competitions, which have since rebranded or evolved. While the changes are mainly about keeping terminology accurate, they help authorities target problematic fan behavior more clearly. No major impacts on businesses, individuals, or the economy are expected, as the law’s focus remains unchanged: promoting safety at top-tier football events.

title: The Football Spectators (Prescription) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: The government has updated regulations that determine which football matches and leagues are covered by the Football Spectators Act 1989, which allows authorities to issue football banning orders to people likely to cause disturbances at games. This includes tweaking the names of leagues like the National League, Women’s Super League, and Cymru Premier to match their current official titles, plus adding a new organization—the Women’s Super League Football Limited—to the listed groups. These changes are largely administrative, ensuring that authorities can apply rules consistently as league structures evolve, but they aren’t expected to lead to major practical effects for fans, clubs, or businesses. However, the upgrade could help reinforce crowd safety measures at women’s top-tier matches by formally aligning them with men’s leagues in the legal framework.

title: The Social Security (Contributions) (Amendment No. 6) Regulations 2025
summary: These regulations make it clear that compensation payments under the Horizon Convictions Redress Scheme won’t count toward National Insurance contributions for more people affected by miscarriages of justice tied to the Horizon system. This includes individuals whose convictions were overturned by law or courts, those issued cautions, offered alternatives to prosecution (or unresolved cases in Scotland), or acquitted after facing charges. By shielding these payments from National Insurance, the change ensures recipients retain their full compensation, offering relief to those combating the financial fallout of past wrongful legal outcomes. Though the rules reinforce existing tax policy rather than introducing new changes, they expand protections to a wider group, streamlining redress without anticipated major consequences for businesses, the economy, or government operations.

title: The Combined Authorities (Adult Education Functions) (Amendment) Order 2025
The Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) (Threshold Amount) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This law raises the financial thresholds for certain money laundering exemptions in the UK, meaning banks and businesses in regulated sectors can handle larger amounts of suspicious cash or assets before triggering criminal penalties. Specifically, the limit for banks operating customer accounts has doubled from £1,000 to £3,000, while the threshold for returning property to clients when ending a business relationship has also increased. Originally set at £250 in 2022 and then raised to £1,000, this latest jump is designed to reduce administrative pressures on financial institutions and firms dealing with low-risk transactions. While it may streamline processes for businesses handling small-scale flagged funds, critics could argue it risks allowing more illicit activity to slip through, though the government says it balances compliance costs with security needs, citing an economic analysis available online.

title: The Justice and Security (Northern Ireland) Act 2007 (Extension of Duration of Non-jury Trial Provisions) Order 2025
summary: This law originally allowed certain serious criminal trials in Northern Ireland to be held without a jury, with a built-in expiration date of July 2009. However, the government has repeatedly extended this deadline by two years each time, and the latest change pushes the final expiration to July 31, 2027. The law applies to cases where juries are deemed impractical or unsafe, often involving terrorism or organized crime. While it’s unlikely to impact most people directly, legal experts note it maintains flexibility for the justice system to adapt to ongoing security challenges. No formal assessment of economic or social impacts was carried out, as officials don’t expect significant effects on businesses, public services, or communities. Critics argue non-jury trials risk undermining fair trial rights, but supporters claim they’re necessary to protect court integrity in high-risk cases.

title: The Horizon Convictions Redress Scheme (Amendment) and Grenfell Support (Restorative Justice) Programme (Income Tax Exemption) Regulations 2025
summary: The government has updated tax rules to ensure certain compensation payments aren’t taxed, helping people who were wrongly impacted by two major cases. If you were convicted, cautioned, or faced prosecution due to issues with the flawed Horizon IT system (used by businesses and post offices) and had those charges overturned or resolved without a conviction, payments from the redress scheme will now be exempt from income tax, capital gains tax, and inheritance tax—all effective retroactively from June 2025. Similarly, payments made since June 2024 under the Grenfell Tower fire support program, which aids those affected by the 2017 disaster, won’t count as taxable income. These changes mean recipients keep more of the compensation they’re owed without worrying about tax bills, offering clearer financial relief for both groups. For Horizon cases, this could benefit hundreds of people who lost livelihoods or faced reputational harm, while Grenfell survivors and families will have less financial stress as they rebuild their lives.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Castle of Mey) Regulations 2025
The A282 Trunk Road (Dartford-Thurrock Crossing Charging Scheme) (Variation) Order 2025
summary: The UK’s Dartford-Thurrock Crossing, a major Thames River route, will see a 40% increase in toll charges under a revised charging system that bills drivers electronically without requiring them to stop. While the update builds on the existing 2013 framework for busy road users, the government hasn’t conducted a full review to determine the effect on commuters, local businesses, or efforts to reduce congestion and emissions. A jump this high could strain household budgets, nudge drivers toward alternative routes, or reduce crossings, potentially impacting regional traffic flow and business activity. Revenue from the hike may fund road upkeep or other transport projects, though the exact consequences remain unclarified.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Balmedie, Aberdeen) Regulations 2025
The Court of Protection (Amendment) Rules 2025
summary: These updates to the Court of Protection rules clarify procedures for handling contempt and committal cases. They remove an outdated reference, ensure defendants in committal hearings are warned that staying silent might lead the court to assume they’re hiding something (in line with criminal cases), and adjust how identities are protected in contempt proceedings. Courts will now weigh non-disclosure of a defendant’s identity early in hearings to avoid privacy breaches later, and judges gain more flexibility to shield identities during contempt cases—though this won’t apply if someone is ultimately sent to prison for contempt. Judgments will only be published when a committal sentence is given. Since these changes align with existing legal practices and case law, they’re unlikely to affect the public, businesses, or government operations significantly.

title: The Justice and Security (Northern Ireland) Act 2007 (Extension  of Duration of Non-jury Trial Provisions) Order 2025
The Bank Recovery and Resolution (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These new rules update how UK banks prepare for financial crises by adjusting the Bank of England’s powers to set buffer requirements (known as MREL) that ensure banks can absorb losses if they fail. Now, when the Bank sets these requirements, it can phase them in gradually over time (a “transitional period”) to help institutions smoothly build up their financial cushions rather than scrambling to meet strict deadlines overnight. The changes also ensure the Bank considers banks’ ability to access emergency recapitalisation payments—which act like a safety net—and aligns its decisions with published policy guidelines. While most adjustments target technical legal frameworks overseen by other regulators (like the PRA or FCA), the overall goal remains to stabilize the banking system without disrupting everyday financial services, meaning ordinary customers, businesses, and the public sector could see fewer risks from bank failures in the future.

title: The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Markets in Financial Instruments) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This law changes rules around financial contracts linked to commodities (like oil, gas, or minerals) by giving the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) more power to ask for details and step in if they spot issues. Previously, the FCA’s oversight was limited, but now they can apply these powers to a broader range of contracts. Businesses in trading sectors might need to share more information, but the government says there won’t be major effects on companies, public services, or everyday life. A short study on the potential minimal impacts is available online, but the changes mainly aim to ensure financial markets stay stable and fair without disrupting regular operations.

title: The Childcare Payments (Eligibility) (Amendment and Transitional Provisions) Regulations 2025
summary: These new rules change when parents can apply for childcare top-up payments to match the longer application window for free childcare under the "FCWP scheme." Previously, top-up payments had a strict 31-day application window, while the free childcare scheme allowed up to 6 months. Starting September 15, 2025, most applicants will use the expanded window, making it easier to access both benefits simultaneously. If you’re expected to start or return to work between October 16, 2025, and January 31, 2026, a phased transition will apply, smoothing the shift to the new system. The change aims to reduce pressure on working parents—especially those returning from maternity, paternity, or adoption leave—by giving them more time to submit paperwork. This could mean fewer ineligible applications due to missed deadlines and better support for families balancing work and care costs, potentially easing financial strain and encouraging workforce participation.

title: The Thames Estuary Cockle Fishery (No. 2) (Variation) Order 2025
summary: This law changes the rules about who can get a permit to harvest cockles in the Thames Estuary, which was originally set to be managed by the Kent and Essex fisheries authority for 28 years under an earlier 2024 order. The tweak loosens some eligibility restrictions for licenses, aiming to balance conservation with supporting local fishing activities. While the government expects no major impacts on businesses, public services, or the economy, the adjustment could influence how cockle populations are maintained, potentially affecting the estuary’s ecosystem and small-scale fishers who rely on the resource. However, since a full review found no significant risks, changes to daily operations or costs for most involved are likely minimal.

title: The Financial Services and Markets Act 2023 (Commencement No. 10 and Saving Provisions) Regulations 2025
The Bank Resolution (Recapitalisation) Act 2025 (Commencement) Regulations 2025
summary: The Bank Resolution (Recapitalisation) Act 2025’s final provisions (Sections 1–7) will kick in on 16th July 2025, completing the law’s rollout after Section 8 took effect earlier this year on 15th May. While the government doesn’t expect this to cause significant changes for businesses, public services, or everyday life, it marks a key step in strengthening the legal framework for stabilizing troubled banks. Advocates argue this could help head off future financial crises, but since the law is mainly procedural and no big operational shifts are anticipated, direct impacts—like new costs or rules for individuals or companies—are unlikely before 2025’s summer cutoff.

title: The Disability Premium Compensation Scheme (Income Tax Exemption) Regulations 2025
summary: These regulations create a tax exemption for certain compensation payments made by public bodies or the UK government, backdating it to December 18, 2024, so recipients won’t pay income tax on them. The move follows a court ruling that identified unfair treatment in disability benefits: some people transitioning from older benefits (“legacy benefits”) to Universal Credit lost out compared to those who stayed on the old system. To fix this, the 2023 and 2024 UCTPA Regulations added payments to Universal Credit awards for those affected, tax-free from February 14, 2024. The Scheme now covers compensation for gaps before that date. While this doesn’t change tax policy overall, it means eligible claimants—many with severe disabilities—can receive more income without tax deductions, improving financial stability and addressing historic inequities in the benefits system. Businesses or organizations involved in administering such payments may need to update records or processes, but the broader economic or environmental impact is unlikely to be significant.

title: The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities etc.) (Amendment) Order 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Northwood) (Emergency) (Revocation) Regulations 2025
The Postal Services (Universal Postal Service) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This law updates rules for postal services in the UK to reflect changes after leaving the EU and improve domestic delivery standards. It adjusts how "working days" are calculated for mail routing by excluding weekends and public holidays, with stricter rules for standard letters (which now exclude Saturdays too). Priority mail must be delivered and collected every weekday through Saturday, while standard letters follow a Monday-to-Friday schedule for both, ensuring faster service for high-value or time-sensitive items. Businesses might see minor cost increases due to these adjustments, though exact impacts are detailed in a public report by regulator OFCOM. The changes aim to balance streamlined operations with meeting customer expectations in a post-EU landscape.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Ayr) Regulations 2025
The Childcare (Miscellaneous Amendments) (England) Regulations 2025
summary: The UK government has updated early childhood education rules to reflect changes in assessment methods and data requirements, replacing outdated references to now-defunct Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) assessment scales with new targets tied to specific learning goals for children under five—like counting, communication, or social skills. These changes give inspectors more authority to enforce the EYFS Progress Check for childminders and group-based providers (e.g., nurseries), but schools doing their own reception-year assessments won’t face extra oversight. The overhaul also tweaks how nurseries report children’s data: “sex” now replaces “gender” to align with official categories, and information about special educational needs matches what schools already collect. While the tweaks mainly align systems and remove obsolete terms, some providers might need to adjust their processes, potentially affecting how they track and improve children’s outcomes. The government plans to publish impact assessments on costs and compliance, but overall, the goal is to streamline early education rules without major disruption.

title: The Civil Nuclear Police Authority (Borrowing Limit) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: The Civil Nuclear Police Authority—a specialized body overseeing nuclear site security in the UK—is getting a boost to its financial flexibility. This law raises its borrowing limit from £10 million to £30 million, allowing it to cover costs related to protecting nuclear facilities and materials being transported, without seeking fresh government approval each time. While the change sounds big, officials don’t expect significant effects on businesses, public services, or the economy, as the authority already had permission to borrow up to £10 million. The increase is likely aimed at pre-empting future security needs, such as advanced equipment or expanded operations, to ensure nuclear sites and materials stay safe. For most people, this won’t change daily life directly, but it could mean stronger safeguards for nuclear infrastructure, which carries obvious importance given the risks involved.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Royal Portrush, Northern Ireland) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (London Southend Airport) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The Meteorological Office Trading Fund (Maximum Borrowing) (Revocation and Saving) Order 2025
summary: The Meteorological Office Trading Fund (which finances the UK's weather services and climate research) has seen its borrowing limit adjusted over time, starting at £200 million in 1996, rising to £300 million in 2019, and most recently increasing to £400 million in 2024. While the 2024 rule bumping the limit to £400 million was initially proposed under a procedure that allowed both Houses of Parliament to review it, a recent change fixes that misstep by revoking the 2024 order to align with the long-standing law (since 1973) that only the House of Commons can override such borrowing decisions. Crucially, this correction ensures the £400 million cap stays in place, maintaining the Met Office's ability to fund critical infrastructure like weather forecasting technology and climate projects. Since the change is procedural and the borrowing limit itself isn’t altered, there’s no expected knock-on effect for individuals, businesses, or the environment—but it reinforces smooth financial oversight by tightening parliamentary accountability. Think of it as a quiet housekeeping tweak to avoid legal hiccups while letting the Met Office keep investing in services that help everyone from farmers planning crops to airlines managing travel disruptions.

title: The Asian Development Bank (Thirteenth Replenishment of the Asian Development Fund) Order 2025
summary: The UK government has approved a payment of up to £120 million to the Asian Development Bank to support its efforts helping developing countries in Asia reduce poverty and boost prosperity. This funding forms part of a broader international agreement—the bank’s thirteenth round of financial contributions—and will be paid in instalments following a resolution passed in October 2024. As part of the deal, the UK will also cancel some old financial notes owed to the bank, which carry no interest and can’t be traded. While the direct impact on everyday people in the UK is expected to be minimal, the contribution aids long-term global development projects, such as infrastructure, education, or climate initiatives in Asia. This aligns with the UK’s international aid commitments and could strengthen economic ties with Asian nations over time. Details about the original agreements are publicly available via the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Manchester) Regulations 2025
The Criminal Justice Act 2003 (Suitability for Fixed Term Recall) Order 2025
summary: This new law changes the rules about releasing prisoners who’ve been sent back to jail after breaking their parole or license conditions. Previously, adults serving sentences of less than 12 months were usually automatically released after 28 days (or 14 days if their sentence was under 12 months), unless they were linked to serious offenses, terrorism, or required higher-risk monitoring. Now, the criteria have tightened: automatic release applies only to those aged 18 or older with sentences under four years, excluding anyone convicted of offenses listed in a new category (Schedule 19AA), involved in terrorism, recalled for another crime, or needing strict supervision under “multi-agency public protection arrangements” (MAPPA levels 2 or 3). If a prisoner faces a new serious charge or is deemed a terror risk *after* being told they’ll be released automatically, authorities can delay their release and shift them to a more considered process involving the Parole Board or Secretary of State. The result? Fewer early releases for higher-risk offenders or those tied to severe crimes (including those now listed in Schedule 19AA), which could mean safer communities but longer detention periods for some prisoners. Conversely, lower-risk individuals with shorter sentences might still benefit from quicker reentry into society. The government’s Impact Assessment warns this might increase administrative workload for the justice system but aims to balance public safety with efficient prisoner management.

The Power to Award Degrees etc. (LTE Group Limited) Order 2025
summary: This new law allows LTE Group Limited—a private education provider—to award specific qualifications for courses they teach from January 1, 2026, to December 31, 2029, without needing ongoing government oversight. While the decision doesn’t impact businesses, charities, or public sector operations, it means students enrolled in LTE Group courses during that timeframe could earn accredited qualifications directly through the organization, potentially expanding access to specialized training or degrees they offer. For most of the public, the change is subtle: it formalizes LTE Group’s ability to confer degrees independently for four years but doesn’t trigger broader policy shifts, cost changes, or regulatory adjustments elsewhere. If they’re studying with LTE Group, though, this could streamline graduation processes by cutting out third-party accreditation steps.

The Housing (Right to Buy) (Designated Rural Areas and Designated Regions) (England) Order 2025
summary: This new regulation officially labels specific parishes as rural areas under a decades-old housing law, ensuring stricter rules apply when certain homes there are sold. In the City of Colchester and East Hampshire district, local authorities can now add protections—like requiring homes to be resold at an affordable price or giving priority buyers’ rights—to preserve housing for local residents. While the government claims there won’t be major impacts on sectors, the move could slow down property sales in these areas and influence market prices, aiming to keep rural communities from becoming hotspots for second homes or unaffordable buy-to-let investments. For homeowners, this might mean added hurdles if they plan to sell, but could help others secure reasonably priced homes where they’re most needed.

title: The Football Spectators (Seating) (Amendment) (England) Order 2025
summary: The Football Spectators (Seating) Order 2022 requires Premier League and Championship stadiums in England and Wales to follow strict seating rules during designated matches to ensure safety, banning standing areas unless licensed. This newer law updates those rules by reflecting Everton Football Club’s recent move to a new stadium, ensuring the same safety standards apply to their matches in the fresh venue. Since the update is simply about redirecting the existing requirements to the club’s new location, it’s not expected to impose new costs or major changes for fans, businesses, or authorities. While the tweak itself is technical, it keeps pressure on clubs to maintain safe conditions for spectators—no standing crowds in all-seater stadiums—potentially shaping how fans experience games, though in Everton’s case, it’s more of a bureaucratic handover than a game-changer.

title: The Safety of Sports Grounds (Designation) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary:

Specifically, football stadiums in England and Wales with seating for over 5,000 spectators—and tied to top-tier leagues like the Football League or Premier League—are now included, while other sports grounds only require certification if they hold more than 10,000. The update adjusts existing rules (from 2015) to reflect recent changes, such as shifts in league memberships or stadium capacities, but the government doesn’t expect it to create significant new costs or burdens for local councils, businesses, or sports teams. However, venues near these thresholds may need to reassess to ensure safe crowd management, particularly if construction dates or league status have changed. The aim is to maintain safety standards without disrupting existing operations or stifling smaller clubs and events.

This new law requires large sheep slaughterhouses to track and report details about carcass quality and prices, aiming to bring more transparency to the meat market. These businesses must now officially tell the government they’re covered by the rules, classify each carcass using set standards as they weigh it (after assigning a trackable ID number), label them correctly, and share pricing data with authorized officials. While most must follow strict manual checks, some can use automated systems approved by the government. The goal is to standardize how meat is priced, potentially giving farmers clearer insights into how their livestock is valued and improving fair competition. Enforcement includes spot checks by officials, fines for non-compliance, and a process to appeal penalties. Officials claim this won’t significantly affect businesses or costs, though some may need to update reporting systems initially. The move could streamline operations over time and ensure suppliers get consistent market data, though it remains to be seen if this will lead to broader changes in pricing or sustainability practices.

The Marketing of Fruit Plant and Propagating Material (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update the 2017 regulations about selling fruit plants and seeds in England. They tweak definitions, update technical terms for pests and plant types to match current scientific standards, and clarify labeling rules—now, labels must say if a plant variety is genetically modified and list any modified organisms. Some outdated wording is corrected, and a previous requirement for government reviews is scrapped. The changes reflect recent EU updates and evaluations, but the government says they won’t have a big impact on businesses or organizations.

title: The Investigatory Powers (Communications Data) (Relevant Public Authorities and Designated Senior Officers) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update who can request access to people’s communications data (like phone records or internet activity) under the Investigatory Powers Act. Certain government departments and agencies—like the Intellectual Property Office, the Department for Transport, and fraud investigation teams in other departments—can now ask for this data, but only for strict reasons, such as fighting serious crime, national security, or public safety. Some agencies, like ambulance services in Scotland and Wales, have lost this power altogether. The changes limit exactly which teams in each department can make these requests and for what specific purposes. The government says these updates won’t have a major impact on businesses or the public.

title: The Health and Care Act 2022 (Commencement No. 10 and Transitional and Saving Provision) Regulations 2025
summary: Starting 7th July 2025, these rules activate section 95 of the Health and Care Act 2022, which updates how information standards work in health and social care. It broadens who must follow these standards—applying them to anyone doing regulated activities—and gives the Secretary of State power to set rules for creating and enforcing these standards. The changes also let the government check if organisations are complying and request information to monitor this. Transitional measures ensure that any standards published before 2025 stay under the old rules until they’re updated. More details are in the official impact assessment, which you can get online or by post.

The Pollution Prevention and Control (Fees) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update the charges for work done by government staff overseeing offshore oil and gas environmental regulations. The changes bump up the hourly rates from £201 to £210 for specialist workers and from £104 to £114 for non-specialists. The fees are calculated based on hours worked multiplied by these rates. There’s no full impact assessment because the changes aren’t expected to seriously affect businesses or the public sector.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Cowdenbeath) (Emergency) (Revocation) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Cowdenbeath) (Emergency) Regulations 2025

The Electricity Act 1989 (Requirement of Consent for Solar Generating Stations) (England) Order 2025
summary: The law used to say you couldn’t build or run a power station over 50 megawatts without government approval. Now, for solar power stations, that limit has been raised to 100 megawatts—meaning bigger solar projects can go ahead without needing separate permission. The government has also checked how this change will affect costs for businesses and the public, and they’ll publish those findings later.

title: The Scotland Act 1998 (Increase of Borrowing Limits) Order 2025
summary: This update increases how much the Scottish government can borrow—raising the regular spending limit from roughly £1.78 billion to £1.83 billion, and the investment (capital) limit from around £3.05 billion to £3.14 billion. It replaces the previous 2024 borrowing rules, which are now cancelled. No detailed impact report was needed because the change isn’t expected to noticeably affect charities or public services.

title: The Customs (Preferential Trade Arrangements and Tariff Quotas) (US) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks UK customs rules to add a new trade deal with the US, specifically allowing a set amount of American beef to be imported at lower tariffs (quota 05.4010). It also updates the official list of UK trade agreements to include the "Economic Prosperity Deal" signed with the US in May 2025. The government says these changes won’t have a big impact on businesses or the public, as they mostly keep existing rules in place. A full analysis wasn’t done because the adjustments are minor. More background was already covered in a 2021 tax policy note.

title: The Customs (Tariff and Miscellaneous Amendments) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update several UK customs documents to align with EU changes, fix errors, and add or remove codes. They tweak tariff rates, adjust definitions for imported goods (including special treatments for items from Colombia, Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, and Moldova), and simplify some procedures—like setting a quota for Colombian bananas or adding extra duties on urea from Russia and Belarus. Since these changes are mostly technical—updating existing rules rather than introducing new ones—no major impact on businesses or the public is expected. Any future updates to these documents can be made without needing new laws.

title: The Criminal and Civil Legal Aid (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules change how legal aid works by cutting out some of the old paperwork and fees. They remove the need for people to make financial contributions for civil or criminal legal aid, meaning eligible individuals won’t have to pay anything upfront. The updates also streamline the process—legal aid providers no longer need to send certain notifications to themselves (like confirming they've issued legal aid), and decisions about eligibility or withdrawing services have been simplified. For ongoing cases, any unpaid contributions will be waived when these rules take effect, though people can't game the system by reapplying for the same legal issue just to avoid past fees. Some decisions made after late June 2025 will also be backdated to earlier in the year. The changes aim to make the system less bureaucratic without major costs to the public sector.

title: The Medical Devices and Blood Safety and Quality (Fees Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update increases fees for medical devices, blood safety, and related services by 9-16%, with some clinical investigation fees rising more. The changes follow public consultation and affect registration, approvals, and clinical studies. Small businesses get more time to pay certain fees. A new optional paid service for regulatory advice is introduced, replacing an old fee. The adjustments apply to UK-wide rules, including Northern Ireland-specific regulations. Full details of the costs and consultation feedback are available on the MHRA and legislation websites.

title: The Tuberculosis in Animals (England) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This update tweaks the rules on tuberculosis in animals in England, making minor changes to the 2021 order. The government says these changes won’t have a big enough effect on farmers, charities, or public services to require a full impact review. It’s essentially a small adjustment, not a major policy shift.

title: The Online Safety Act 2023 (Fees Notification) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules explain what information online service providers must give to Ofcom when notifying them under Section 83 of the Online Safety Act. The details help Ofcom work out any fees the provider needs to pay. The rules list specific evidence and documents required, as well as how providers must submit them—following Ofcom’s published guidelines. No separate business cost assessment was done, as this relates to fee calculations, but Ofcom did review the rules' impact in its public consultation and policy statement. You can find all the documents on Ofcom’s and the government’s legislation websites.

title: The Local Authorities (Referendums and Election of Mayors) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks two sets of rules about how local councils in England can switch to a mayoral system. If enough people in an area sign a petition between July 2025 and the next election day in 2026, the local council must hold a referendum within six months after that election. If voters approve a mayor in the referendum (or if the council decides to have one without a referendum), the first mayoral election will happen at the second regular election after the decision was made. The changes don’t expect to cause any major effects on businesses or public services. More details are available online.

title: The Customs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks several UK customs rules, mostly around imports, exports, and postal shipments. Key changes include: fines up to £1,000 for failing to move goods to designated inspection areas when required, easier temporary import declarations (allowing verbal or automated processes in some cases), and adjustments to how goods are valued for customs duty—like accounting for defective items. It also lets certain foreign postal operators handle UK-bound shipments more easily and scraps paper paperwork for air/rail transit shipments. Most new processes will be detailed in online HMRC notices, available to view in person if needed. Some changes won’t take full effect until 2026, giving businesses time to adapt.

title: The Reporting Cryptoasset Service Providers (Due Diligence and Reporting Requirements) Regulations 2025
summary: These regulations bring in new rules based on international standards for cryptoasset service providers operating in the UK. If you run a crypto trading platform or facilitate crypto exchanges and have ties to the UK, you’ll need to follow stricter checks on your users, report their details to HMRC, and tell them their info is being shared. You must keep records for five years and register with HMRC. There are penalties for failing to comply, but you won’t be fined if you have a good excuse. The rules also cover how penalties are applied, appeals, and measures to stop people dodging the system. More details on how this affects taxes can be found online.

title: The International Tax Compliance (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks the UK’s international tax rules to match global standards for sharing financial information, particularly covering crypto assets. Starting in 2026, banks and financial institutions must follow new reporting requirements, including registering with HMRC and sharing extra details about certain transactions. Some deadlines are extended, like those for credit card issuers and excluded accounts, while old rules no longer needed (like client notifications) are removed. There are also new penalties for failing to provide required tax info or register properly. The changes align with the latest 2023 global tax framework and streamline definitions and processes. The full details are explained in a separate tax impact note online.

title: The Electricity Act 1989 (Requirement of Consent for Solar Generating Stations) (England) Order 2025
summary: This rule updates the Electricity Act 1989, which normally requires government approval to build, expand, or run large power stations over 50 megawatts. The change allows solar power stations to operate at up to 100 megawatts without needing this specific consent. The government has checked how this will affect costs for businesses, charities, and public services, and will release those details separately.

title: The Scotland Act 1998 (Increase of Borrowing Limits) Order 2025
summary: This update raises the Scottish Government's borrowing limits—increasing the "resources" limit from roughly £1.78 billion to £1.83 billion and the "capital" limit from around £3.05 billion to £3.14 billion. It replaces the previous borrowing limit increase from early 2024, which is now cancelled. No major impacts on public services or charities are expected, so no detailed assessment was needed.

title: The Customs (Preferential Trade Arrangements and Tariff Quotas) (US) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules update existing customs regulations to add a new special quota (05.4010) for US beef imports, which comes from a trade deal between the UK and US signed on 8 May 2025. They also tweak the list of official trade agreements to include this new arrangement. The government says there’s no need for a full assessment of the changes because they won’t really affect businesses or the public—most of this just keeps existing rules in place, and the broader impacts were already covered in a 2021 report.

title: The Customs (Tariff and Miscellaneous Amendments) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks several UK customs documents to keep them in line with EU changes, fix errors, and adjust trade agreements. It updates cargo codes, removes outdated ones, and revises rules about certain imports – like adding a banana trade quota for Colombia and extra duties on urea from Russia and Belarus. It also scraps some old Ukraine and Moldova-related customs rules that aren’t needed anymore. Most changes are technical, so there’s no major impact expected for businesses or the public.

title: The Criminal and Civil Legal Aid (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update changes several legal aid rules to simplify the process and remove fees. It scraps the requirement for people to pay contributions for civil legal aid and eases administrative burdens—like no longer forcing providers to send unnecessary paperwork to themselves. Changes also cover criminal legal aid, like backdating eligibility in some cases and removing duplicate financial checks for Crown Court cases after a magistrates’ court decision. Existing cases will generally follow the new rules, waiving unpaid contributions, but people can’t reapply just to dodge old fees. Some new rules apply retroactively to May 2025. The government says these tweaks won’t significantly impact public sector costs.

title: The Medical Devices and Blood Safety and Quality (Fees Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules increase fees for medical devices, blood safety, and related services. Most fees rise by 9% to 16%, with steeper hikes for clinical investigations. The changes follow public consultation and apply to things like registering devices, approving testing bodies, and clinical trial oversight. Small companies get more time to pay some fees. There's also a new optional service—paid regulatory advice—replacing an old fee. Updates for Northern Ireland mirror these changes. The full cost breakdown is available online.

title: The Tuberculosis in Animals (England) (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This order tweaks the rules on tuberculosis in animals in England, updating the 2021 regulations. No major impact is expected for businesses or organisations, so there’s no formal assessment of the changes. Just a straightforward adjustment to keep things running smoothly.

title: The Online Safety Act 2023 (Fees Notification) Regulations 2025
summary: These rules explain what online service providers must give Ofcom (the UK’s communications regulator) when reporting certain details under the Online Safety Act 2023. This helps Ofcom work out what fees the provider needs to pay. The rules specify what proof or documents must be sent, how to send them—referencing Ofcom’s published guidelines—and note that no separate business cost assessment was done because it relates to fees. Ofcom did, however, assess the rules’ impact during public consultations, with updates in their final policy statement. More details are available on their website.

title: The Local Authorities (Referendums and Election of Mayors) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This update tweaks the rules around local government referendums and elected mayors in England. If enough people petition to change how their council is run between July 2025 and the next election day in 2026, the vote must happen within six months after that election. If they choose to switch to a mayoral system, the first mayor election will happen at the second regular election after the decision. The same timing applies if councils skip a referendum and directly choose a mayoral system. These changes smooth out the process without making things harder - it's just adjusting dates to keep everything running smoothly around election times.
